care.watering: Water sparingly. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Every 2-3 weeks in summer, monthly in winter.
care.sunlight: Very adaptable. Thrives in bright indirect light but tolerates low light and even some direct sun. Avoid prolonged direct afternoon sun.
care.pruning: Minimal pruning needed. Remove dead or damaged leaves at the base with clean scissors. Can divide plant when repotting.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Leaves turning soft and yellow, mushy at the base. Soil is constantly wet.
troubleshooting.solution: Severe overwatering and possible root rot. Stop watering immediately. Remove affected leaves. Repot in fresh, well-draining soil if roots are mushy. Water much less frequently.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Leaf tips turning brown and dry. Otherwise plant looks healthy.
troubleshooting.solution: Usually caused by fluoride or chlorine in tap water, or inconsistent watering. Use filtered or distilled water. Ensure soil dries completely between waterings.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Leaves becoming soft, curling, or drooping. Plant losing rigidity.
troubleshooting.solution: If soil is bone dry for extended period: Water thoroughly. If soil is wet: Root rot from overwatering. Check roots and repot if necessary.

troubleshooting.symptoms: White, brown, or red-brown spots on leaves. May spread over time.
troubleshooting.solution: Likely fungal infection from overwatering or poor air circulation. Remove affected leaves, reduce watering, ensure good airflow, and avoid wetting leaves.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Small insects, sticky residue, or visible bugs on leaves.
troubleshooting.solution: Snake plants rarely have pests. If present, wipe leaves with alcohol or insecticidal soap. Check for mealybugs or spider mites and treat accordingly.

faqs.q: How often should I water my Snake Plant?
faqs.a: Water only when soil is completely dry, typically every 2-3 weeks in summer and monthly in winter. Snake plants are drought-tolerant and prefer underwatering to overwatering.

faqs.q: Can Snake Plants grow in low light?
faqs.a: Yes! Snake Plants are one of the best low-light houseplants. They'll grow slower in low light but still thrive.

faqs.q: Why is my Snake Plant falling over?
faqs.a: Overwatering causes root rot which makes leaves soft and unable to stand upright. Reduce watering and check if roots are healthy.
